ratings.question_text: How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: N/A
I previously didn't know anything about green energy policy and now I know the basics
Class discussions
Getting a good idea for the political obstacles and possibilities for creating green energy policy in the USA.

The interaction of the class materials and lectures with the events in real time. I believe this inclusion of news and happenings in the energy sector to the course material made it dynamic. This evolving characteristic of the discussions and the up to date information in this field made the class an extraordinary learning experience.
The opportunity to learn from a practitioner and an academic about some of the most salient issues in the field.
The class discussions and the information/experience/prospective that the prof brought to the class.
Great readings!
Professor Elliott is an expert in this field. The final group project solidifed knowledge gained during the course.
I liked the discussion about current issues (e.g., Solyndra).
This course provides a decent overview of renewable energy and policies in the U.S.
Learning arguments for and against a position.
The reading material provided was excellent and the instructor sent around recent articles relating to class discussion.
The readings all of them were pretty informative. The class discussions were interesting too.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: more structured lecture and class discussion
N/A

I think the course should go deeper into the theories behind the different policy ideas we discussed. I felt at times it was just a barrage of ideas and I had no framework through which to evaluate them.
Perhaps it would strengthen the team work sessions if some guidelines and requirements were developed for this activity.
The professor was at times a bit repetitive and strayed from the main topics presented in the syallabus.
The course was still pretty basic and I would have preferred it to be a little more rigorous. The professor and students both were pretty laid back and I think the course suffered as a result.

This course would greatly benefit from weekly assignments or reading responses. It would also be helpful if the lectures were more structured and used slides to guide the lectures. It was hard staying motivated with the readings without any assignments throughout the semester.
The lectures lack structure and there is no clear indication what the central aspects of the lecture are. This is unfortunate since the instructor's explanations are generally very interesting.
The group project needs to be more defined. I feel that we lost a lot of time at the beginning but not having a clear definition of what was expected.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: prof was very available
N/A
The instructor always responded e-mails and was very comprehensive of any issue. He always helped the group into keeping up with the different news breaking in the field.
No TA. The prof was always available to answer questions or talk outside of class.
Very responsive professor.

Professor Elliott emailed me right away when I emailed him about my final paper topic. When I emailed him back with follow-up questions, however, he did not respond. He also did not provide much guidance on the final paper or presentation.
The professor was available.
excellent
Excellent

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: The course provided a good introduction to energy policy and renewable energy topics.
This is a policy oriented class and I'm most interested in the environmental policy field. I feel this is a great asset to have under my wing when I go out into the work force.
I am interested in renewable energy.
Policy processes and policy making - focus
The course fit into my overall schedule quite nicely, since it offered many very interesting sources.
Energy concentration.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I just wanted to take one course while at Yale on green energy and this fit into my schedule and seems to fit my needs.
To learn more about green energy.

To gain an understanding of green energy policy in the USA: the key obstacles, and ways that have been proposed to get over those obstacles. Which policies are effective; which are unequitable; which have been proposed by which parties/actors, and why.

I took this course because of three reasons. First, it was taught by a Law school professor and Yale Law school is a great school and great opportunity for forestry students to have this type of joint courses. Second, because it was the last time it was offered as it was and next semester the syllabus is going to change so I wanted to take it before it was too late. Third, green energy in the US is certainly a salient issue to know in order to be able to understand the trends of innovation in the country and its influence to other commercial partners.
Sounded very interesting.
Wanted to fill in gaps of knowledge.
I am interested in renewable energy and this was a good primer on the policy options.
Interested in energy and there are not that many energy courses offered.

This course helped give an overview of green energy policy. I wanted to get a foundation in this topic in general so that I would be able to help businesses incorporate renewable energy into their practices.
Interest
As a supplement for more technical energy classes
Get a better understanding of US energy policy.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: Not really - I wanted a more engaging class discussion and lecture. The professor was a bit too casual with seemingly unstructured lectures - lots of rambling and tangents.
Yes.
Pretty much, though I would have liked to have studied more theory - see my comment above
This course lived up to my expectations very well.
Yes
Yes.
Yes.
I had heard mixed reviews so I would say my expectations were met.
This course somewhat lived up to my expectations. I didn't come away having learned a ton about green energy, but this is mostly my fault for not keeping up with the readings.
yes
Sometimes it seemed very repetitive of other classes, but class discussions overall proved to be interesting-
Yes.

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: sort of
Yes.
See previous answer

I got out of this course what I expected, and I could add that I got an extra learning experience by writing the final paper. It felt nice to have applied the concepts reviewed in class to a working policy in implementation.
Yes
Yes.
Yes. There was a lot of good reading material and Professor Elliott was very approachable.
Was hoping to get more.
Not entirely, but this is because I didn't keep up with the readings. It would have been helpful if we had weekly assignments to keep up accountable for the readings.
yes
Partly - it could have been more beneficial if the lectures had a clearer structure and focused only on policy issues.
Yes.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: advantage: got to know classmates better since there was no class discussion
N/A
The group work towards the end of semester was a great opportunity to discuss the ideas we'd visited during the course.

The work group had very interesting discussion sessions. I appreciated the different schools the participants came from, which undoubtedly increased the richness of the discussions. One suggestion would be to develop a guideline for the group assignments to better materialize the products of the discussions.
Advantages- I learned more about the topic that we worked on. It also gave me the chance to engage with students in a way that I normally would not have.Disadvantages- None.
Better understanding of the overall objectives of the course.
We did a group project at the end of the semester. It was great to work with SOM, law, and FES students and to hear everyone's perspectives.
Difficult to get people together. Was very hands off in approach, such that everyone did their own part. Therefore the product was not cohesive.
Group work was excellent and we could benefit from each others' experience in the sector.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: expect a very casual, unstructured class - you get out what you put in.
N/A

Unfortunately this course is no longer offered as it was. One advice for students taking any other class with Don Elliott is to have as many questions ready as possible, since he has an outstanding understanding of the politics behind the policies.
The coursework is lightbut there is a lot to gain if you do all the readings and make the class a priority.
Have medium expectations and you won't be disappointed.

This course gives you a nice foundation in green energy policy. However, you must keep up with the readings to get anything out of the course. Start the group project early as this makes it more fun and you'll learn more from it. The ending paper is a good chance to review what you learned in the course.
Read.
If you already have an energy background parts of the lectures are not very interesting. The readings though are great and a very central part of the class.
Engage in class discussions.
